posts.title: Revolution and youth are closely allied.
posts.body: can a revolution promise to adults? To some it brings disgrace, to others favor. But even that favor is questionable,

posts.title: The point was we took this shit very
posts.body: seriously. They had taken away our flowers, our summer days, and our bonuses, we were on a wage freeze and a hiring freeze, and people were flying out the door like so many dismantled dummies.

posts.title: The old scholar was watching the noisy
posts.body: young people around him and it suddenly occurred to him that he was the only one in the whole audience who had the privilege of freedom,

posts.title: Later, on my walk, I wondered why I felt I
posts.body: had to be suspicious of 'normality'. The striking thing about the normal is that there is nothing normal about it:

posts.title: Looking back on those incidents,
posts.body: always appalled by the memory of his passivity, hard though it was to see what else he could have done. He could have refused to pay for the gravy damage to his room, could have refused to change his shoes,

posts.title: I hoped she did not dislike me,
posts.body: under no illusions that she might remember me in any way fondly; that is, if she remembered me at all. I was but one of a procession; I provided extra food, drink, that day some tobacco, beyond that I did not exist for her.

posts.title: If I may so express it, I was steeped in Dora.
posts.body: was not merely over head and ears in love with her, but I was saturated through and through. Enough love might have been wrung out of me, metaphorically speaking,

posts.title: Lyrical poetry is a realm in which any
posts.body: statement immediately becomes truth. Yesterday the poet said life is a vale of tears; today he said life is a land of smiles; and he was right both times. There is no inconsistency.

posts.title: Sometimes, when Chapuys has finished
posts.body: digging up Walter's bones and making his own life unfamiliar to him, he feels almost impelled to speak in defense of his father, his childhood. But it is no use to justify yourself. It is no good to explain. It is weak to be anecdotal.

posts.title: Always I had acted as if a third person was watching
posts.body: Always I had acted as if a third person was watching and listening and giving me marks for good or bad behaviour - a god like a novelist, to whom I turned, like a character with the power to please, the sensitivity to feel slighted, the ability to adapt himself to whatever he believed the novelist-god wanted.

posts.title: What was I after all?
posts.body: Near enough what Conchis had had me told: nothing but the net sum of countless wrong turnings. I dismissed most of the Freudian jargon of the trial; but all my life I had tried to turn life to fiction, to hold reality away.

posts.title: Now they were in the earth
posts.body: Now they were in the earth to which they had given their lives; and slowly, year by year, the earth would take them.

posts.title: He thought of the cost exacted
posts.body: He thought of the cost exacted, year after year, by the soil; and it remained as it had been—a little more barren, perhaps, a little more frugal of increase. Nothing had changed. Their lives had been expended in cheerless labor, their wills broken, their intelligences numbed.

posts.title: He buried her beside her husband
posts.body: He buried her beside her husband. After the services were over and the few mourners had gone, he stood alone in a cold November wind and looked at the two graves, one open to its burden and the other mounded and covered by a thin fuzz of grass.

posts.title: I was disconcerted, for I had broken away
posts.body: I was disconcerted, for I had broken away without quite seeing where I was going to. It was not to be shuffled off now, however, and I answered, `The beautiful young lady at Miss Havisham's, and she's more beautiful than anybody ever was, and I admire her dreadfully, and I want to be a gentleman on her account.'

posts.title: You must thrive in spite of yourself
posts.body: You must thrive in spite of yourself; and so that you may do it, God takes out your heart of flesh, and gives you a heart of stone.

posts.title: He once thought it himself, that he might die
posts.body: He once thought it himself, that he might die with grief: for his wife, his daughters, his sisters, his father and master the cardinal. But pulse, obdurate, keeps its rhythm. You think you cannot keep breathing, but your ribcage has other ideas, rising and falling, emitting sighs.˝

posts.title: On foot, from necessity or in deference
posts.body: On foot, from necessity or in deference to his dismounted commander or associates, his conduct was the same. He would stand like a rock in the open when officers and men alike had taken to cover;

posts.title: He stood over the body in the fading light
posts.body: Adjusting the hair and putting the finishing touches to the simple toilet, doing all mechanically, with soulless care. And still through his consciousness ran an undersense of conviction that all was right—that he should have her again as before, and everything explained.

posts.title: A secret always has a strengthening effect
posts.body: A secret always has a strengthening effect upon a newborn friendship, as does the shared impression than an external figure is to blame: the men of the Crown have become united less by their shared beliefs, we observe, than by their shared misgivings.

posts.title: A judgment that is necessarily hampered
posts.body: A judgment that is necessarily hampered, bot only by the scope and limits of his imagination, but by the ever-changing measure of his doubt and self-esteem.

posts.title: For although a man is judged by his actions
posts.body: For although a man is judged by his actions, by what he has said and done, a man judges himself by what he is willing to do, by what he might have said, or might have done

posts.title: Everything failed to subdue me
posts.body: Everything failed to subdue me. Soon everything seemed dull: another sunrise, the lives of heroes, failing love, war, the discoveries people made about each other.

posts.title: In the hospital men's room
posts.body: In the hospital men's room, as I'm washing my hands, I glance in the mirror. The man I see is not so much me as my father. When did he show up? There is no soap; I rub hand sanitizer into my face-it burns. I nearly drown myself in the sink trying to rinse it off.

posts.title: But just as I didn't want to resent my kids
posts.body: I also didn't want to find myself too much in love with them. There are parents who don't like to hear their little girl crying at night, at the vast approaching dark of sleep, and so in their torment think why not feed her a lollipop, and a few years later that kid's got seven cavities and a pulled tooth.

posts.title: Christ, he thinks, by my age I ought to know
posts.body: You don't get on by being original. You don't get on by being bright. You don't get on by being strong. You get on by being a subtle crook;

posts.title: They look so fine, and young
posts.body: They look so fine, and young, and wrapped up in each other. Love is so fresh and clean at that age. Don't you think?

posts.title: Your only chance of survival
posts.body: Your only chance of survival, if you are sincerely smitten, lies in hiding this fact from the woman you love, of feigning a casual detachment under all circumstances.

posts.title: During the first part of your life
posts.body: During the first part of your life, you only become aware of happiness once you have lost it. Then an age comes, a second one, in which you already know, at the moment when you begin to experience true happiness.

posts.title: Were you in love with her?
posts.body: The question is in a way meaningless, she knows, but one must ask. Love in such situations is rarely real. Sex is the engine, exalting and ruining people, sex and frustration. Love is what people believe is worth the path of devastation.
